dataset.title: The dung beetle fauna in two vegetation types near Punda Maria, Kruger National Park, South Africa

abstract.para: Dung beetles have been proposed as potential bio-indicators for other invertebrates. To be effective bio-indicators, the group must exhibit sensitivity to environmental changes. We sampled the dung beetle fauna in two vegetation types near Punda Maria Camp in Kruger National Park over a two-day period in September 2010. Baited pitfall traps were used to collect dung beetle samples. We measured dung type and density, sampled soil and conducted vegetation surveys at our study sites. A total of 431 dung beetle specimens composed of seven species were collected. Species richness and the distributions of individual species differed between different vegetation and soil types. Our results suggest that dung beetle faunas differ with vegetation type and soil conditions. The family does seem to exhibit the habitat sensitivity required of a bio-indicator.

section.title: Methods
section.para: Study site:

Our study was conducted east of Punda Maria Camp in the northern region of Kruger National Park, Limpopo Province, South Africa. Data was collected over a four-day period from the 10th to the 13th of September 2010. To examine if either similarity in vegetation type or the distance between sampling sites had a greater influence on the dung beetle fauna, we chose two study sites with similar vegetation, Colophospermum mopane, but far apart and one site with a mixed woodland that neighbored one of the mopane sites. Site 1 (22º 75’ S, 031º15’E) and Site 2 (22º69’S, 031º03’E) were 18 km apart and both dominated by C. mopane (Figure 1). Site 3 (22º69’ S, 031º08’E) was approximately 0.5 km from Site 2 and was a mixed woodland (Figure 1). Our decision to collect data at only three sites, two mopane-dominated and one without mopane, was influenced by the time constraints we operated under.
Figure 1. Photographs of Site 1 (A), Site 2 (B) and Site 3 (C)
A cold front occurred at the time of our specimen collection. Our time restrictions did not permit further sampling under more typical seasonal conditions.
Beetle specimen collection and processing:

To collect dung beetles, we constructed pitfall traps using soap, water, chicken wire, a funnel, a small bucket and elephant dung. We inserted a bucket filled with water and soap into a 30 cm deep hole and positioned a funnel and chicken wire over its top. A dung packet was placed over the chicken wire so beetles lured to the trap by its scent would walk, or fly, onto the wire and fall through the funnel’s hole into the bucket where we collected them the following morning (Figure 2).
Figure 2. Cross-section of pitfall trap used to collect dung beetles.

Five traps were set about 25 m apart at each site. Specimens were collected on two separate mornings, placed into alcohol jars and then pinned and labeled. The beetles were examined under a microscope and organized into morpho species. Several groups could not be identified to species level and were designated with a letter preceded by their genus name (See Appendix A for photographs of species).
Measuring of explanatory variables:

To determine environmental differences among sites, we examined three factors that contribute to dung beetle distributions (Davis et al. 2008). We measured the density of dung present, surveyed vegetation and sampled soil at each site.
Dung density sampling:

Dung found at the study sites was classified into one of three categories based on fiber content, bolus and size (Davis et al. 2008): 1) pellets (dung of rodents and some ungulates) 2) coarse dung of non-ruminant herbivores (i.e. elephants) 3) fine dung forming a pad, mostly of ruminant herbivores (i.e. buffalo).

At each site, we employed two methods of measuring the density of dung present. The first was to collect, weigh and classify all dung found in four 8 m X 8 m quadrants, with a dung beetle trap as a center point. This method was used for the area around the two traps closest to the road at each site (Figure 3A). In the second method, we collected, weighed and classified all dung from a 20 m X 50 m transect that began near the third trap from the road at each site (Figure 3B).
Figure 3. The quadrant method (A) sampled dung around one trap, while the transect method (B) sampled dung in a small rectangular section at each site.
Soil sampling:

Two surface and two subsurface (20 cm below the surface) soil samples were taken at each dung beetle trap for a total of 20 samples per study site. These soils were examined using the finger test for texture to determine soil type (Brown 2002).
Vegetation survey:

At each site we sampled two 30 m transects. All plants and that fell within 5 cm of either side of each transect and their heights were recorded. Woody plants were identified to the species level where possible, but grasses were simply recorded as poaceae.
Data analysis:

Species richness and abundance of dung beetles were compared among the three sites using a Kruskal-Wallis test and between sites using a Mann-Whitney test. The tests were carried out using the program Statistica. The Kruskal-Wallis and Mann-Whitney tests were then used to determine if the sites differed in their abundance of specific species. To show the difference between trap contents at each site, we displayed the auto-spatial correlation of our data after graphing S17 Bray Curtis Similarity data for all 15 traps with the program Primer v6.

section.title: Site Data
section.para: Site Data: Limpopo Province of South Africa, KNP, Punda Maria
• Site 1: (S22.75073, E31.14937) 18 km away from sites 2 and 3, dominated by Colophospermum mopane
• Site 2: (S22.69227, E31.02797) 0.5 km away from site 3, dominated by Colophospermum mopane
• Site 3: (S22.68980, E31.08439) mixed woodland, (no Colophospermum mopane)
• Weather conditions: The dung beetle traps were set the afternoon of 10 September 2010. By the evening a cold front moved in and it rained overnight.
